description.body:
The keyword used to start a conditional block.

Executes the following code block only if the specified condition evaluates to true. Can be followed by optional 'Else If' and 'Else' keywords.

Example Customizations:
- `if`
- `condition`
- `check`
- `?`
- `<CheckCondition>`

Defaults to: **`if`**.

The keyword for subsequent conditional checks if the preceding 'if' or 'else if' conditions were false.

Example Customizations:
- `else if`
- `elseif`
- `elif`
- `otherwise if`
- `?:if`

Defaults to: **`else if`**.

The keyword for the final block in an if-chain, executed if all preceding 'if' and 'else if' conditions were false.

Example Customizations:
- `else`
- `otherwise`
- `default`
- `_`
- `<?:`

Defaults to: **`else`**.

The keyword to start a loop that continues as long as the specified condition remains true.

Example Customizations:
- `while`
- `loop while`
- `repeat if`
- `condition loop`
- `WHILE_LOOP`

Defaults to: **`while`**.

The keyword to start an infinite loop (similar to AHK `Loop`). Requires a 'break' statement inside to exit.

Example Customizations:
- `Loop`
- `loop forever`
- `repeat`
- `infinite`
- `FOREVER`

Defaults to: **`Loop`**.

The keyword (often followed by a comma or specific syntax) to start a loop that iterates a specific number of times (similar to AHK `Loop, N`). Uses `A_Index`.

Example Customizations:
- `Loop,`
- `loop N`
- `repeat N`
- `times`
- `COUNT_LOOP:`

Defaults to: **`Loop,`**.

The keyword (often followed by specific syntax) to start a loop that iterates over substrings of a string, based on delimiters (similar to AHK `Loop, Parse`). Uses `A_LoopField`.

Example Customizations:
- `Loop, Parse,`
- `loop parse`
- `for each in`
- `split loop`
- `PARSE_STRING:`

Defaults to: **`Loop, Parse,`**.

Specifies the keyword used to define a new function, procedure, or subroutine.

Example Customizations:
- `func`
- `function`
- `def`
- `proc`
- `DEFINE_FUNC`

Defaults to: **`func`**.

The keyword to start a block of code where exceptions might occur.

Example Customizations:
- `try`
- `attempt`
- `guard`
- `monitor`
- `BEGIN_TRY`

Defaults to: **`try`**.

The keyword to start a block that handles exceptions caught in the preceding 'try' block.

Example Customizations:
- `catch`
- `except`
- `on error`
- `handle`
- `ON_ERROR`

Defaults to: **`catch`**.

The keyword to start a block that executes after the 'try' and any 'catch' blocks, regardless of whether an exception occurred.

Example Customizations:
- `finally`
- `ensure`
- `always`
- `cleanup`
- `AFTER_TRY`

Defaults to: **`finally`**.

Top-level organizational container keyword in Ordinal Struct Programming (OSP).

Example Customizations:
- `alliance`
- `namespace`
- `group`
- `domain`
- `OSP_GROUP`

Defaults to: **`alliance`**.

Sub-level organizational container keyword within an 'alliance' in OSP.

Example Customizations:
- `crew`
- `subgroup`
- `section`
- `unit`
- `OSP_SUB`

Defaults to: **`crew`**.

Keyword used to define a procedure (function) within an OSP 'alliance' or 'crew'.

Example Customizations:
- `proc`
- `procedure`
- `action`
- `method`
- `DEFINE_P`

Defaults to: **`proc`**.

Keyword used to define a structure (data container) in OSP.

Example Customizations:
- `struct`
- `structure`
- `record`
- `data`
- `DEFINE_S`

Defaults to: **`struct`**.

Represents the absence of a return value for functions.

Example Customizations:
- `void`
- `nothing`
- `empty`
- `nil_type`
- `TYPE_VOID`

Defaults to: **`void`**.

Represents a double-precision floating-point number.

Example Customizations:
- `double`
- `float64`
- `real`
- `precise`
- `TYPE_DBL`

Defaults to: **`double`**.

Represents a single character.

Example Customizations:
- `char`
- `character`
- `letter`
- `rune`
- `TYPE_CHR`

Defaults to: **`char`**.

Represents an 8-bit unsigned integer (0 to 255).

Example Customizations:
- `uint8`
- `byte`
- `u8`
- `octet`
- `TYPE_U8`

Defaults to: **`uint8`**.

Represents a 16-bit unsigned integer.

Example Customizations:
- `uint16`
- `ushort`
- `u16`
- `word`
- `TYPE_U16`

Defaults to: **`uint16`**.

Represents a 32-bit unsigned integer.

Example Customizations:
- `uint32`
- `uint`
- `u32`
- `dword`
- `TYPE_U32`

Defaults to: **`uint32`**.

Represents a 64-bit unsigned integer.

Example Customizations:
- `uint64`
- `ulong`
- `u64`
- `qword`
- `TYPE_U64`

Defaults to: **`uint64`**.

Represents a standard signed integer (size may vary by target language).

Example Customizations:
- `int`
- `integer`
- `num`
- `i32`
- `TYPE_INT`

Defaults to: **`int`**.

Represents a sequence of characters (text).

Example Customizations:
- `str`
- `string`
- `text`
- `char*`
- `TYPE_STR`

Defaults to: **`str`**.

Represents a logical value, either true or false.

Example Customizations:
- `bool`
- `boolean`
- `flag`
- `logic`
- `TYPE_BOOL`

Defaults to: **`bool`**.

Represents a single-precision floating-point number.

Example Customizations:
- `float`
- `float32`
- `single`
- `decimal`
- `TYPE_FLT`

Defaults to: **`float`**.

Represents an 8-bit signed integer (-128 to 127).

Example Customizations:
- `int8`
- `sbyte`
- `i8`
- `tinyint`
- `TYPE_I8`

Defaults to: **`int8`**.

Represents a 16-bit signed integer.

Example Customizations:
- `int16`
- `short`
- `i16`
- `smallint`
- `TYPE_I16`

Defaults to: **`int16`**.

Represents a 32-bit signed integer.

Example Customizations:
- `int32`
- `signed int`
- `i32`
- `integer`
- `TYPE_I32`

Defaults to: **`int32`**.

Represents a 64-bit signed integer.

Example Customizations:
- `int64`
- `long`
- `i64`
- `bigint`
- `TYPE_I64`

Defaults to: **`int64`**.

Operator used to join two strings together.

Example Customizations:
- `.`
- `+`
- `++`
- `&`
- `..`

Defaults to: **`.`**.

Operator for numerical addition.

Example Customizations:
- `+`
- `add`
- `plus`
- `sum`
- `__ADD__`

Defaults to: **`+`**.

Operator for numerical subtraction.

Example Customizations:
- `-`
- `sub`
- `minus`
- `diff`
- `__SUB__`

Defaults to: **`-`**.

Operator for numerical multiplication.

Example Customizations:
- `*`
- `mul`
- `times`
- `product`
- `__MUL__`

Defaults to: **`*`**.

Operator for numerical division.

Example Customizations:
- `/`
- `div`
- `divide`
- `quotient`
- `__DIV__`

Defaults to: **`/`**.

Operator to get the remainder of a division.

Example Customizations:
- `%`
- `mod`
- `rem`
- `remainder`
- `__MOD__`

Defaults to: **`%`**.

Operator for raising a number to a power.

Example Customizations:
- `**`
- `^`
- `pow`
- `power`
- `__EXP__`

Defaults to: **the "**" value**.

Operator to check if two values are equal (loose equality).

Example Customizations:
- `==`
- `is`
- `eq`
- `equals`
- `=`

Defaults to: **`==`**.

Operator to check if two values are equal *and* of the same type (if applicable).

Example Customizations:
- `===`
- `is exactly`
- `strict eq`
- `seq`
- `IS_STRICT`

Defaults to: **`===`**.

Operator to check if two values are not equal.

Example Customizations:
- `!=`
- `is not`
- `ne`
- `not eq`
- `<>`

Defaults to: **`!=`**.

Operator to check if the left value is greater than the right value.

Example Customizations:
- `>`
- `gt`
- `greater`
- `more`
- `GT`

Defaults to: **`>`**.

Operator to check if the left value is less than the right value.

Example Customizations:
- `<`
- `lt`
- `less`
- `fewer`
- `LT`

Defaults to: **`<`**.

Operator to check if the left value is greater than or equal to the right value.

Example Customizations:
- `>=`
- `ge`
- `gte`
- `at least`
- `GE`

Defaults to: **`>=`**.

Operator to check if the left value is less than or equal to the right value.

Example Customizations:
- `<=`
- `le`
- `lte`
- `at most`
- `LE`

Defaults to: **`<=`**.

Logical operator returns true if both operands are true.

Example Customizations:
- `and`
- `&&`
- `&`
- `both`
- `AND_LOGIC`

Defaults to: **`and`**.

Logical operator returns true if at least one operand is true.

Example Customizations:
- `or`
- `||`
- `|`
- `either`
- `OR_LOGIC`

Defaults to: **`or`**.

Logical operator that inverts the boolean value of its operand.

Example Customizations:
- `!`
- `not`
- `~`
- `invert`
- `NOT_LOGIC`

Defaults to: **`!`**.

Performs a bitwise AND operation.

Example Customizations:
- `&`
- `bitand`
- `band`
- `bitwise_and`
- `BIT_A`

Defaults to: **`&`**.

Performs a bitwise OR operation.

Example Customizations:
- `|`
- `bitor`
- `bor`
- `bitwise_or`
- `BIT_O`

Defaults to: **`|`**.

Performs a bitwise XOR (exclusive OR) operation.

Example Customizations:
- `^`
- `bitxor`
- `bxor`
- `exclusive_or`
- `BIT_X`

Defaults to: **`^`**.

Performs a bitwise NOT (complement) operation.

Example Customizations:
- `~`
- `bitnot`
- `bnot`
- `complement`
- `BIT_N`

Defaults to: **`~`**.

Shifts bits to the left.

Example Customizations:
- `<<`
- `shl`
- `shiftl`
- `lshift`
- `BIT_SL`

Defaults to: **`<<`**.

Shifts bits to the right (sign-propagating).

Example Customizations:
- `>>`
- `shr`
- `shiftr`
- `rshift`
- `BIT_SR`

Defaults to: **`>>`**.

Shifts bits to the right (zero-filling).

Example Customizations:
- `>>>`
- `ushr`
- `ushiftr`
- `urshift`
- `BIT_USR`

Defaults to: **`>>>`**.

The first symbol in a ternary conditional expression (condition ? value_if_true : value_if_false).

Example Customizations:
- `?`
- `then`
- `??`
- `iftrue`
- `TERN1`

Defaults to: **`?`**.

The second symbol in a ternary conditional expression, separating the true and false values.

Example Customizations:
- `:`
- `else`
- `::`
- `iffalse`
- `TERN2`

Defaults to: **`:`**.

The primary operator used to assign a value to a variable.

Example Customizations:
- `=`
- `:=`
- `<-`
- `set`
- `<-=`

Defaults to: **`=`**.

Adds the right operand to the left operand and assigns the result to the left operand.

Example Customizations:
- `+=`
- `add=`
- `inc=`
- `sum_set`
- `+:=`

Defaults to: **`+=`**.

Concatenates the right string to the left string and assigns the result.

Example Customizations:
- `.=`
- `concat=`
- `append=`
- `join_set`
- `.:=`

Defaults to: **`.=`**.

Subtracts the right operand from the left operand and assigns the result.

Example Customizations:
- `-=`
- `sub=`
- `dec=`
- `diff_set`
- `-:=`

Defaults to: **`-=`**.

Multiplies the left operand by the right operand and assigns the result.

Example Customizations:
- `*=`
- `mul=`
- `times_set`
- `prod_set`
- `*:=`

Defaults to: **`*=`**.

Divides the left operand by the right operand and assigns the result.

Example Customizations:
- `/=`
- `div=`
- `divide_set`
- `quot_set`
- `/:=`

Defaults to: **`/=`**.

Computes the modulo and assigns the result.

Example Customizations:
- `%=`
- `mod=`
- `rem_set`
- `mod_set`
- `%:=`

Defaults to: **`%=`**.

Performs a bitwise left shift and assigns the result.

Example Customizations:
- `<<=`
- `shl=`
- `lshift_set`
- `<<:=`
- `lshAss`

Defaults to: **`<<=`**.

Performs a bitwise right shift (signed) and assigns the result.

Example Customizations:
- `>>=`
- `shr=`
- `rshift_set`
- `>>:=`
- `rshAss`

Defaults to: **`>>=`**.

description.header: Unsigned Right Shift and Assign Operator
description.body:
Performs an unsigned bitwise right shift and assigns the result.

Example Customizations:
- `>>>=`
- `ushr=`
- `urshift_set`
- `>>>:=`
- `urshAss`

Defaults to: **`>>>=`**.

Performs a bitwise AND and assigns the result.

Example Customizations:
- `&=`
- `band=`
- `bitand_set`
- `&:=`
- `bAndAss`

Defaults to: **`&=`**.

Performs a bitwise OR and assigns the result.

Example Customizations:
- `|=`
- `bor=`
- `bitor_set`
- `|:=`
- `bOrAss`

Defaults to: **`|=`**.

Performs a bitwise XOR and assigns the result.

Example Customizations:
- `^=`
- `bxor=`
- `bitxor_set`
- `^:=`
- `bXorAss`

Defaults to: **`^=`**.

Keyword to define a generic array. In dynamic languages, type is inferred. In static languages, defaults typically to an array of strings.

Example Customizations:
- `arr`
- `array`
- `list`
- `vec`
- `[_]`

Defaults to: **`arr`**.

Keyword combination to define an array specifically containing integers.

Example Customizations:
- `arr int`
- `array<int>`
- `list_int`
- `vec[int]`
- `[int]`

Defaults to: **`arr int`**.

Keyword combination to define an array specifically containing strings.

Example Customizations:
- `arr str`
- `array<str>`
- `list_str`
- `vec[str]`
- `[str]`

Defaults to: **`arr str`**.

Keyword combination to define an array specifically containing floating-point numbers.

Example Customizations:
- `arr float`
- `array<float>`
- `list_float`
- `vec[float]`
- `[float]`

Defaults to: **`arr float`**.

Keyword combination to define an array specifically containing booleans.

Example Customizations:
- `arr bool`
- `array<bool>`
- `list_bool`
- `vec[bool]`
- `[bool]`

Defaults to: **`arr bool`**.

Syntax used to call the method that adds an element to the end of an array.

Example Customizations:
- `.push`
- `.add`
- `.append`
- `.put`
- `.ad`

Defaults to: **`.push`**.

Syntax used to call the method that removes and returns the last element of an array.

Example Customizations:
- `.pop`
- `.removeLast`
- `.pull`
- `.pl`
- `.rmlst`

Defaults to: **`.pop`**.

Syntax used to call the method that returns the number of elements in an array.

Example Customizations:
- `.size`
- `.length`
- `.count`
- `.sz`
- `.len`

Defaults to: **`.size`**.

Syntax used to call the method that inserts an element at a specific index in an array.

Example Customizations:
- `.insert`
- `.addAt`
- `.put`
- `.istrAtIndex`
- `.ins`

Defaults to: **`.insert`**.

Syntax used to call the method that removes the element at a specified index from an array.

Example Customizations:
- `.rm`
- `.removeAt`
- `.delete`
- `.del`
- `.gone`

Defaults to: **`.rm`**.

Syntax used to call the method that returns the index of the first occurrence of a specified element in an array.

Example Customizations:
- `.indexOf`
- `.find`
- `.search`
- `.A_IndexOf`
- `.idx`

Defaults to: **`.indexOf`**.

Keyword to start a generic block of code intended for the target transpiled language.

Example Customizations:
- `___start`
- `_BLOCK_START_`
- `BEGIN_RAW`
- `<<<`
- `{%`

Defaults to: **`___start`**.

Keyword to end a generic block of code intended for the target transpiled language.

Example Customizations:
- `___end`
- `_BLOCK_END_`
- `END_RAW`
- `>>>`
- `%}`

Defaults to: **`___end`**.

Specific keyword to start a block of native C++ code.

Example Customizations:
- `___cpp start`
- `_CPP_BEGIN_`
- `RAW_CPP{`
- `<<<cpp`
- `cpp:`

Defaults to: **`___cpp start`**.

Specific keyword to end a block of native C++ code.

Example Customizations:
- `___cpp end`
- `_CPP_END_`
- `}RAW_CPP`
- `cpp>>>`
- `:cpp`

Defaults to: **`___cpp end`**.

Specific keyword to start a block of native Python code.

Example Customizations:
- `___py start`
- `_PY_BEGIN_`
- `RAW_PY{`
- `<<<py`
- `py:`

Defaults to: **`___py start`**.

Specific keyword to end a block of native Python code.

Example Customizations:
- `___py end`
- `_PY_END_`
- `}RAW_PY`
- `py>>>`
- `:py`

Defaults to: **`___py end`**.

- `ts:`

Example Customizations:
- `___groovy start`
- `_GROOVY_BEGIN_`
- `RAW_GROOVY{`
- `<<<groovy`
- `groovy:`

Defaults to: **`___groovy start`**.

Specific keyword to end a block of native Groovy code.

Example Customizations:
- `___groovy end`
- `_GROOVY_END_`
- `}RAW_GROOVY`
- `groovy>>>`
- `:groovy`

Keyword to start a block of code that will *only* be included when the target language is another HTVM syntax (HTVM-to-HTVM conversion).

Example Customizations:
- `___htvm start`
- `_HTVM_TGT_BEGIN_`
- `RAW_HTVM{`
- `<<<htvm_tgt`
- `htvm_tgt:`

Defaults to: **`___htvm start`**.

Keyword to end a block of HTVM-targeted code.

Example Customizations:
- `___htvm end`
- `_HTVM_TGT_END_`
- `}RAW_HTVM`
- `htvm_tgt>>>`
- `:htvm_tgt`

Defaults to: **`___htvm end`**.

Keyword used *inside* a native language file (like `.cpp`) to mark the beginning of a block that contains HTVM source code, intended for reverse processing.

Example Customizations:
- `___inhtvm start`
- `_HTVM_SRC_BEGIN_`
- `HTVM{`
- `<<<htvm_src`
- `htvm_src:`

Defaults to: **`___inhtvm start`**.

Keyword used *inside* a native language file to mark the end of an HTVM source code block.

Example Customizations:
- `___inhtvm end`
- `_HTVM_SRC_END_`
- `}HTVM`
- `htvm_src>>>`
- `:htvm_src`

Defaults to: **`___inhtvm end`**.

Represents a null or non-existent value. Behavior may vary in target languages.

Example Customizations:
- `null`
- `nil`
- `None`
- `undefined`
- `NULLPTR`

Defaults to: **`null`**.

Represents the boolean true value.

Example Customizations:
- `true`
- `True`
- `yes`
- `on`
- `yeah`

Defaults to: **`true`**.

Represents the boolean false value.

Example Customizations:
- `false`
- `False`
- `no`
- `off`
- `nah`

Defaults to: **`false`**.

Skips the rest of the current loop iteration and proceeds to the next one.

Example Customizations:
- `continue`
- `skip`
- `next`
- `CONT`
- `->`

Defaults to: **`continue`**.

Exits the current loop structure immediately.

Example Customizations:
- `break`
- `exit loop`
- `stop`
- `BREAK`
- `<-`

Defaults to: **`break`**.

Used within async functions to pause execution until a Promise (or equivalent asynchronous operation) settles.

Example Customizations:
- `await`
- `wait`
- `yield`
- `sync`
- `AWT`

Defaults to: **`await`**.

Used to declare an asynchronous function.

Example Customizations:
- `async`
- `waitable`
- `ASYNC`
- `future`
- `@async`

Defaults to: **`async`**.

Used to explicitly raise an exception or error.

Example Customizations:
- `throw`
- `raise`
- `error`
- `exception`
- `THROW!`

Defaults to: **`throw`**.

The name of the function used in conjunction with 'throw' to create an error object or message.

Example Customizations:
- `ErrorMsg`
- `MakeError`
- `Exception`
- `Err`
- `panic`

Defaults to: **`ErrorMsg`**.

Used to exit a function and optionally send a value back to the caller.

Example Customizations:
- `return`
- `ret`
- `yield back`
- `yeet`
- `<-func`

Defaults to: **`return`**.

Keyword for declaring variables (often function-scoped, primarily relevant for JavaScript/TypeScript targets).

Example Customizations:
- `var`
- `variable`
- `VAR`
- `declare`
- `%var%`

Defaults to: **`var`**.

Keyword for declaring block-scoped variables (primarily relevant for JavaScript/TypeScript targets).

Example Customizations:
- `let`
- `local`
- `LET`
- `block var`
- `::`

Defaults to: **`let`**.

Keyword for declaring block-scoped constants (variables whose value cannot be reassigned). Support varies by target language.

Example Customizations:
- `const`
- `constant`
- `final`
- `CONST`
- `readonly`

Defaults to: **`const`**.

Keyword used to explicitly close code blocks (e.g., functions, loops, conditionals) if the 'useEnd' setting is enabled.

Example Customizations:
- `end`
- `end block`
- `END`
- `over`
- `done`

Defaults to: **`end`**.

Keyword used (primarily in Python/AHK targets) inside a function to indicate that an assignment should modify a global variable instead of creating a local one.

Example Customizations:
- `global`
- `GLOBAL`
- `use global`
- `^`
- `scope`

Defaults to: **`global`**.

The character(s) used to start a single-line comment.

Example Customizations:
- `//`
- `;`
- `#`
- `--`
- `REM`

Defaults to: **`//`**.

The character(s) used to start a multi-line comment block.

Example Customizations:
- `/*`
- `'''1`
- `{-`
- `<!--`
- `BEGIN_COMMENT`

Defaults to: **`/*`**.

The character(s) used to end a multi-line comment block.

Example Customizations:
- `*/`
- `'''2`
- `-}`
- `-->`
- `END_COMMENT`

Defaults to: **`*/`**.

Keyword used to include the content of another HTVM file at the current location.

Example Customizations:
- `include`
- `import`
- `require`
- `#include`
- `using`

Defaults to: **`include`**.

Operator to increment a numeric variable (prefix or postfix behavior depends on target language).

Example Customizations:
- `++`
- `inc`
- `+1`
- `increment`
- `INC`

Defaults to: **`++`**.

Operator to decrement a numeric variable (prefix or postfix behavior depends on target language).

Example Customizations:
- `--`
- `dec`
- `-1`
- `decrement`
- `DEC`

Defaults to: **`--`**.

A label indicating the primary entry point for program execution, especially relevant if functions are defined.

Example Customizations:
- `main`
- `start`
- `entry`
- `MAIN Func`
- `__main__`

Defaults to: **`main`**.

The starting value for `A_Index` in counted loops (`Loop, N`), (`Loop, Parse`) or even in the infinite loop. Set to `0` for zero-based indexing or `1` for one-based indexing. Non-numeric values might cause issues.

(!!! NOT RECOMNED TO CHANGE UNLESS FOR SOME MEME LANG !!!)

 Don't set to `1` just for AHK or Lua  HTVM auto-assumes based on the target lang.

Example Customizations:
- `0`
- `1`
- `69`
- `-420`
- `-1`

Defaults to: **`0`**.

The name of the built-in variable holding the current iteration number in counted and infinite loops.

Example Customizations:
- `A_Index`
- `index`
- `i`
- `loop_counter`
- `LOOP_IDX`

Defaults to: **`A_Index`**.

The name of the built-in variable holding the current substring in parsing loops (`Loop, Parse,`).

Example Customizations:
- `A_LoopField`
- `field`
- `item`
- `token`
- `PARSE_VAR`

Defaults to: **`A_LoopField`**.

The character used to escape special characters within strings (e.g., `\n` for newline if `\` is the escape char, or ```n` if ``` is).

Example Customizations:
- ```
- `\`
- `$`
- `%`
- `ESC`

Defaults to: **`\`**.

The character or keyword used to open a code block if the 'useCurlyBraces' setting is enabled.

Example Customizations:
- `{`
- `begin`
- `<`
- `(`
- `<block>`

Defaults to: **`{`**.

The character or keyword used to close a code block if the 'useCurlyBraces' setting is enabled.

Example Customizations:
- `}`
- `end`
- `>`
- `)`
- `</block>`

Defaults to: **`}`**.

Commands offer a simplified, often more concise, way to perform actions, automatically translating to function calls. This section details how to define these command syntaxes in your `HTVM-instructions.txt` file. For a general overview of using already defined commands in your HTVM code, see the main [Commands Documentation](https://github.com/TheMaster1127/HTVM/blob/main/DOCUMENTATION.md#commands).

**Important Note on Scope:** HTVM commands (including `lineTranspile` ones) are processed by the HTVM transpiler *before* code is passed to a target language compiler/interpreter. Therefore, **HTVM commands do not work inside programming blocks** (e.g., `___js start ... ___js end`). Programming blocks are for writing native code directly in the target language, bypassing HTVM's command processing.

## Command Definition Rules in `HTVM-instructions.txt`

The `commands` value in `HTVM-instructions.txt` is a pipe-separated (`|`) list of command definitions. Each definition follows the format: `HTVMCommandName,Rule1,Rule2,ParamName1,ParamName2,...`

Here are the rules for how parameters are handled:

### 1. `OUTVAR` Rule
Specifies that the first parameter in your HTVM command usage will be the variable that receives the result of the function call.
- **Definition Syntax:** `CmdName,OUTVAR,arg1,arg2,...`
- **HTVM Usage (Conceptual):** `CmdName, myOutputVar, val1, val2`
- **Transpiles to (Conceptual):** `myOutputVar = CmdName(val1, val2)`

#### Examples for `OUTVAR`

1.  **Definition:** `CalculateSum,OUTVAR,num1,num2`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        CalculateSum, total, 5, 10
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (e.g., Python-like):**
        ```python
        total = CalculateSum(5, 10)
        ```

2.  **Definition:** `FetchUserData,OUTVAR,userId`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        FetchUserData, userObj, 123
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (e.g., Python-like):**
        ```python
        userObj = FetchUserData(123)
        ```

3.  **Definition:** `GetFileContent,OUTVAR,filePath`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        GetFileContent, fileData, "data.txt"
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (e.g., Python-like):**
        ```python
        fileData = GetFileContent("data.txt")
        ```

4.  **Definition:** `GenerateID,OUTVAR`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        GenerateID, newId
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (e.g., Python-like):**
        ```python
        newId = GenerateID()
        ```

5.  **Definition:** `ConvertToUpper,OUTVAR,textIn`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        ConvertToUpper, upperCaseText, "hello world"
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (e.g., Python-like):**
        ```python
        upperCaseText = ConvertToUpper("hello world")
        ```

6.  **Definition:** `ParseConfig,OUTVAR,fileName`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        ParseConfig, settings, "app.cfg"
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (e.g., Python-like):**
        ```python
        settings = ParseConfig("app.cfg")
        ```

7.  **Definition:** `FindMax,OUTVAR,val1,val2,val3`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        FindMax, maximum, 10, 50, 20
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (e.g., Python-like):**
        ```python
        maximum = FindMax(10, 50, 20)
        ```

8.  **Definition:** `QueryDB,OUTVAR,sql`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        QueryDB, results, "SELECT * FROM users"
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (e.g., Python-like):**
        ```python
        results = QueryDB("SELECT * FROM users")
        ```

9.  **Definition:** `IsServiceRunning,OUTVAR,serviceName`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        IsServiceRunning, status, "WebService"
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (e.g., Python-like):**
        ```python
        status = IsServiceRunning("WebService")
        ```

10. **Definition:** `CreatePoint,OUTVAR,x,y`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        CreatePoint, p1, 0, 0
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (e.g., Python-like):**
        ```python
        p1 = CreatePoint(0, 0)
        ```

### 2. `INVAR` Rule
Specifies that the first parameter in your HTVM command usage will be passed as the *first argument* to the function call. Subsequent parameters in the HTVM command follow as subsequent arguments.
- **Definition Syntax:** `CmdName,INVAR,arg1,arg2,...`
- **HTVM Usage (Conceptual):** `CmdName, myInputVar, val1, val2`
- **Transpiles to (Conceptual):** `CmdName(myInputVar, val1, val2)`

#### Examples for `INVAR`

1.  **Definition:** `PrintValue,INVAR`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        PrintValue, someVariable
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (e.g., Python-like):**
        ```python
        PrintValue(someVariable)
        ```

2.  **Definition:** `LogMessage,INVAR,level`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        LogMessage, "System Critical", "ERROR"
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (e.g., Python-like):**
        ```python
        LogMessage("System Critical", "ERROR")
        ```

3.  **Definition:** `SetValue,INVAR,newValue`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        SetValue, targetVariable, 100
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (e.g., Python-like):**
        ```python
        SetValue(targetVariable, 100)
        ```

4.  **Definition:** `AppendToList,INVAR,item`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        AppendToList, existingList, "new_item"
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (e.g., Python-like):**
        ```python
        AppendToList(existingList, "new_item")
        ```

5.  **Definition:** `UpdateRecord,INVAR,data`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        UpdateRecord, recordIdVar, updatedFieldsVar
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (e.g., Python-like):**
        ```python
        UpdateRecord(recordIdVar, updatedFieldsVar)
        ```

6.  **Definition:** `SendCommandToDevice,INVAR,code`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        SendCommandToDevice, "Device01", 255
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (e.g., Python-like):**
        ```python
        SendCommandToDevice("Device01", 255)
        ```

7.  **Definition:** `SetColor,INVAR,color`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        SetColor, uiElementVar, "red"
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (e.g., Python-like):**
        ```python
        SetColor(uiElementVar, "red")
        ```

8.  **Definition:** `ValidateInput,INVAR,rule`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        ValidateInput, userInputVar, "EMAIL_REGEX"
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (e.g., Python-like):**
        ```python
        ValidateInput(userInputVar, "EMAIL_REGEX")
        ```

9.  **Definition:** `RegisterCallback,INVAR,funcName`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        RegisterCallback, "on_click", MyCallbackHandler
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (e.g., Python-like):**
        ```python
        RegisterCallback("on_click", MyCallbackHandler)
        ```

10. **Definition:** `RunProcess,INVAR`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        RunProcess, "cleanup_script.sh"
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (e.g., Python-like):**
        ```python
        RunProcess("cleanup_script.sh")
        ```

### 3. `INOUTVAR` Rule
Specifies that the first parameter in your HTVM command usage is both an input to the function (as its first argument) and the variable that receives the function's result.
- **Definition Syntax:** `CmdName,INOUTVAR,arg1,arg2,...`
- **HTVM Usage (Conceptual):** `CmdName, myVar, val1, val2`
- **Transpiles to (Conceptual):** `myVar = CmdName(myVar, val1, val2)`

#### Examples for `INOUTVAR`

1.  **Definition:** `Increment,INOUTVAR`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        Increment, counterVar
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (e.g., Python-like):**
        ```python
        counterVar = Increment(counterVar)
        ```

2.  **Definition:** `SortList,INOUTVAR,order`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        SortList, dataArrayVar, "ASC"
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (e.g., Python-like):**
        ```python
        dataArrayVar = SortList(dataArrayVar, "ASC")
        ```

3.  **Definition:** `TrimString,INOUTVAR`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        TrimString, textToTrimVar
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (e.g., Python-like):**
        ```python
        textToTrimVar = TrimString(textToTrimVar)
        ```

4.  **Definition:** `NormalizeData,INOUTVAR,factor`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        NormalizeData, rawValuesVar, 0.5
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (e.g., Python-like):**
        ```python
        rawValuesVar = NormalizeData(rawValuesVar, 0.5)
        ```

5.  **Definition:** `ApplyFilter,INOUTVAR,filter`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        ApplyFilter, imageVar, "BLUR"
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (e.g., Python-like):**
        ```python
        imageVar = ApplyFilter(imageVar, "BLUR")
        ```

6.  **Definition:** `ShuffleArray,INOUTVAR`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        ShuffleArray, cardDeckVar
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (e.g., Python-like):**
        ```python
        cardDeckVar = ShuffleArray(cardDeckVar)
        ```

7.  **Definition:** `SanitizeHTML,INOUTVAR,level`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        SanitizeHTML, htmlContentVar, "strict"
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (e.g., Python-like):**
        ```python
        htmlContentVar = SanitizeHTML(htmlContentVar, "strict")
        ```

8.  **Definition:** `ProcessQueueItem,INOUTVAR`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        ProcessQueueItem, currentItemVar
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (e.g., Python-like):**
        ```python
        currentItemVar = ProcessQueueItem(currentItemVar)
        ```

9.  **Definition:** `UpdateCounter,INOUTVAR,amount`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        UpdateCounter, visitCountVar, 1
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (e.g., Python-like):**
        ```python
        visitCountVar = UpdateCounter(visitCountVar, 1)
        ```

10. **Definition:** `TransformCoordinates,INOUTVAR,matrix`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        TransformCoordinates, pointsVar, matrixVar
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (e.g., Python-like):**
        ```python
        pointsVar = TransformCoordinates(pointsVar, matrixVar)
        ```

### 4. `'parameterName` (Literal String) Rule
Prefixing a parameter name in the definition with a single quote (e.g., `'param1`) means that when the user provides a value for this parameter in their HTVM command, that value will be automatically wrapped in double quotes (`\"\"`) when passed to the transpiled function, treating it as a string literal. **The user does *not* type the single quote in their HTVM code; it's a marker for the definition.** If the HTVM usage provides a value with spaces, HTVM automatically handles quoting for that specific parameter. If the HTVM usage is a single word without spaces for such a parameter, it will also be wrapped in quotes in the transpiled output.
- **Definition Syntax:** `CmdName,'stringArg1,regularArg1,...`
- **HTVM Usage (Conceptual):** `CmdName, Some Text Here, val1` or `CmdName, SingleWord, val1`
- **Transpiles to (Conceptual):** `CmdName(\"Some Text Here\", val1)` or `CmdName(\"SingleWord\", val1)`

#### Examples for `'parameterName`

1.  **Definition:** `ShowAlert,'message`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        ShowAlert, Operation Successful
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (e.g., Python-like):**
        ```python
        ShowAlert(\"Operation Successful\")
        ```

2.  **Definition:** `SetLabel,'text,id`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        SetLabel, User Name, labelIdVar
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (e.g., Python-like):**
        ```python
        SetLabel(\"User Name\", labelIdVar)
        ```

3.  **Definition:** `LogToFile,'entry,'fileName`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        LogToFile, System started, app.log
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (e.g., Python-like):**
        ```python
        LogToFile(\"System started\", \"app.log\")
        ```

4.  **Definition:** `MsgBox,'text` (As in your default example)
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        MsgBox, Hello there friend
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (e.g., Python-like):**
        ```python
        MsgBox(\"Hello there friend\")
        ```

5.  **Definition:** `SetWindowTitle,'title`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        SetWindowTitle, My Application v1.0
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (e.g., Python-like):**
        ```python
        SetWindowTitle(\"My Application v1.0\")
        ```

6.  **Definition:** `CreateFile,'content,name`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        CreateFile, # Empty config, fileNameVar
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (e.g., Python-like):**
        ```python
        CreateFile(\"# Empty config\", fileNameVar)
        ```

7.  **Definition:** `RunScript,'path`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        RunScript, /opt/scripts/backup.sh
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (e.g., Python-like):**
        ```python
        RunScript(\"/opt/scripts/backup.sh\")
        ```

8.  **Definition:** `DisplayHelp,'topic`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        DisplayHelp, Saving Files
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (e.g., Python-like):**
        ```python
        DisplayHelp(\"Saving Files\")
        ```

9.  **Definition:** `SendEmail,'subject,recipient,'body`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        SendEmail, Meeting Reminder, toAddressVar, Dont forget our meeting
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (e.g., Python-like):**
        ```python
        SendEmail(\"Meeting Reminder\", toAddressVar, \"Dont forget our meeting\")
        ```

10. **Definition:** `FindFile,'pattern,'path`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        FindFile, *.txt, /home/user/docs
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (e.g., Python-like):**
        ```python
        FindFile(\"*.txt\", \"/home/user/docs\")
        ```

### 5. `lineTranspile` Rule
If a command definition uses `lineTranspile`, it means that if the HTVM command name appears on a line by itself in the user's code, that entire line will be replaced by the text provided in the third part of the command definition. If this replacement text contains `~~~`, these will be converted into actual newlines in the transpiled code. **The replacement is raw text; no automatic semicolons or language-specific syntax modifications are added beyond what's in the definition.**
- **Definition Syntax:** `CmdName,lineTranspile,Replacement text~~~More replacement text`
- **HTVM Usage (Conceptual):** (CmdName on its own line)
    ```htvm
    CmdName
    ```
- **Transpiles to (Conceptual):** (Raw text replacement)
    ```
    Replacement text
    More replacement text
    ```

#### Examples for `lineTranspile`

1.  **Definition:** `InitApp,lineTranspile,LoadConfig()~~~ConnectDatabase()~~~SetupUI()`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        InitApp
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (Raw Text):**
        ```
        LoadConfig()
        ConnectDatabase()
        SetupUI()
        ```

2.  **Definition:** `StandardHeader,lineTranspile,// Copyright 2024 MyCompany~~~// All rights reserved.`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        StandardHeader
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (Raw Text):**
        ```
        // Copyright 2024 MyCompany
        // All rights reserved.
        ```

3.  **Definition:** `PrintSeparator,lineTranspile,print(\"====================\")`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        PrintSeparator
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (Raw Text):**
        ```
        print(\"====================\")
        ```

4.  **Definition:** `BoilerplateHTML,lineTranspile,<html>~~~<head>~~~<title>Doc</title>~~~</head>~~~<body></body>~~~</html>`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        BoilerplateHTML
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (Raw Text):**
        ```html
        <html>
        <head>
        <title>Doc</title>
        </head>
        <body></body>
        </html>
        ```

5.  **Definition:** `DebugBreak,lineTranspile,debugger`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        DebugBreak
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (Raw Text, e.g. JS):**
        ```javascript
        debugger
        ```

6.  **Definition:** `ResetVars,lineTranspile,x = 0~~~y = 0~~~z = \"\"`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        ResetVars
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (Raw Text, assuming target uses `=` for assignment):**
        ```
        x = 0
        y = 0
        z = \"\"
        ```

7.  **Definition:** `LogTimestamp,lineTranspile,LogMessage(GetCurrentTime(), \"INFO\")`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        LogTimestamp
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (Raw Text):**
        ```
        LogMessage(GetCurrentTime(), \"INFO\")
        ```

8.  **Definition:** `IncludeCommonLibs,lineTranspile,#include <iostream>~~~#include <vector>~~~#include <string>`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        IncludeCommonLibs
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (Raw Text, e.g., C++):**
        ```cpp
        #include <iostream>
        #include <vector>
        #include <string>
        ```

9.  **Definition:** `ExitGracefully,lineTranspile,SaveState()~~~CloseConnections()~~~ExitApp(0)`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        ExitGracefully
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (Raw Text):**
        ```
        SaveState()
        CloseConnections()
        ExitApp(0)
        ```

10. **Definition:** `ShowVersion,lineTranspile,print(\"App Version 1.2.3\")`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        ShowVersion
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (Raw Text):**
        ```
        print(\"App Version 1.2.3\")
        ```

### 6. Regular Parameters (No Special Rule Keyword)
If a parameter name in the definition does not have `OUTVAR`, `INVAR`, `INOUTVAR` before it, and is not prefixed by a single quote (`'`), it's treated as a regular input parameter. Its value from the HTVM command usage is passed directly to the corresponding argument in the function call.
- **Definition Syntax:** `CmdName,param1,param2,...`
- **HTVM Usage (Conceptual):** `CmdName, val1, val2`
- **Transpiles to (Conceptual):** `CmdName(val1, val2)` (This assumes no `OUTVAR`, `INVAR`, or `INOUTVAR` is also present to modify this default behavior. If `OUTVAR` is present, for example, these become regular arguments *after* the assignment.)

#### Examples for Regular Parameters

1.  **Definition:** `DrawRectangle,x,y,width,height,color`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        DrawRectangle, 10, 20, 100, 50, "blue"
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (e.g., Python-like):**
        ```python
        DrawRectangle(10, 20, 100, 50, "blue")
        ```

2.  **Definition:** `MoveObject,objId,newX,newY`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        MoveObject, playerSpriteVar, 500, 300
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (e.g., Python-like):**
        ```python
        MoveObject(playerSpriteVar, 500, 300)
        ```

3.  **Definition:** `SetVolume,level`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        SetVolume, 75
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (e.g., Python-like):**
        ```python
        SetVolume(75)
        ```

4.  **Definition:** `Sleep,duration` (From your default example)
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        Sleep, 1000
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (e.g., Python-like):**
        ```python
        Sleep(1000)
        ```

5.  **Definition:** `ConnectToServer,ip,port`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        ConnectToServer, "192.168.1.100", 8080
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (e.g., Python-like):**
        ```python
        ConnectToServer("192.168.1.100", 8080)
        ```

6.  **Definition:** `WritePixel,x,y,color`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        WritePixel, 5, 15, 0xFF0000
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (e.g., Python-like):**
        ```python
        WritePixel(5, 15, 0xFF0000)
        ```

7.  **Definition:** `ResizeImage,width,height,method`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        ResizeImage, 800, 600, "bicubic"
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (e.g., Python-like):**
        ```python
        ResizeImage(800, 600, "bicubic")
        ```

8.  **Definition:** `AddUserToGroup,user,group`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        AddUserToGroup, userVar, groupVar
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (e.g., Python-like):**
        ```python
        AddUserToGroup(userVar, groupVar)
        ```

9.  **Definition:** `SetTimeout,callback,delay`
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        SetTimeout, MyTimeoutHandlerFunc, 5000
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (e.g., Python-like):**
        ```python
        SetTimeout(MyTimeoutHandlerFunc, 5000)
        ```

10. **Definition:** `Random,OUTVAR,min,max` (Combines `OUTVAR` with regular params)
    *   **HTVM Usage:**
        ```htvm
        Random, randomNumberVar, 1, 100
        ```
    *   **Transpiles to (e.g., Python-like):**
        ```python
        randomNumberVar = Random(1, 100)
        ```


**Important Note:** If `CmdName` corresponds to a special HTVM built-in operation that maps to a differently named function in the target language, HTVM handles that mapping. Otherwise, the `CmdName` itself is used as the function name in the transpiled code.

Example Customizations of Command Definitions (how they might look in the `HTVM-instructions.txt` `commands` string):
- `StringTrimLeft,OUTVAR,INVAR,param1|...`
- `TrimL,OUTVAR,INVAR,num|...`
- `LTrim,out,in,count|...`
- `cmd_trim_left,OUTVAR,INVAR,count|...`
- `REMOVE_LEADING,INOUTVAR,numChars|...`

Defaults to the predefined list: **`StringTrimLeft,OUTVAR,INVAR,param1|StringTrimRight,OUTVAR,INVAR,param1|Random,OUTVAR,param1,param2|Sleep,INVAR|FileRead,OUTVAR,'param1|FileAppend,INVAR,'param1|FileDelete,'INVAR|Sort,INOUTVAR,'param1|MsgBox,'param1`**.

WARNING!!! DO NOT CHANGE THIS, OTHERWISE THE IDE WILL NOT WORK. ONLY MODIFY THIS FOR FUN AND ONLY IF YOU ARE NOT PLANNING TO USE HT-IDE OR ANY OTHER IDE MADE BY US!

The preferred file extension for source files written in this custom HTVM language.

Example Customizations:
- `htvm`
- `myht`
- `htv`
- `hsc`
- `script`

Defaults to: **`htvm`**.

The default programming language HTVM will transpile the code into if not specified otherwise. Choose from the 15 supported languages (e.g., cpp, py, js, etc.).

Example Customizations:
- `cpp`
- `py`
- `js`
- `go`
- `lua`

Defaults to: **`cpp`**.

Keyword used within an OSP 'struct' to define a data field (property).

Example Customizations:
- `prop`
- `property`
- `field`
- `member`
- `data`

Defaults to: **`prop`**.

Special parameter name within an OSP 'proc' that receives the calling struct's full path as a string for context.

Example Customizations:
- `this`
- `self`
- `context`
- `current`
- `CALLER_PATH`

Defaults to: **`this`**.

Enable this to use `{` and `}` (or custom equivalents defined by `keyWordCurlyBraceOpen`/`Close`) to define code blocks. Mutually exclusive with 'Use End Keyword' and 'Use Pythonic Colon Syntax'.

Defaults to: **`on`**.

Enable this to use the `keyWordEnd` keyword (e.g., 'end') to close code blocks (like Lua/Ruby). Mutually exclusive with 'Use Curly Braces'.

Defaults to: **`off`**.

Enable this to require semicolons `;` at the end of statements.

Defaults to: **`off`**.

Enable this to require parentheses `()` around conditions in `if`, `else if`, and `while` statements.

Defaults to: **`on`**.

Enable this to use C-style prefix type definitions (e.g., `int x`). Mutually exclusive with 'Use Postfix Type Definition'.

Defaults to: **`on`**.

Enable this to use postfix type definitions (e.g., `x: int`). Mutually exclusive with 'Use Prefix Type Definition'.

Defaults to: **`off`**.

Enable this to use Python-style colons `:` at the end of lines starting blocks (like `if`, `while`, `func`) and rely on indentation. Mutually exclusive with 'Use Curly Braces'.

Defaults to: **`off`**.

description.header: Use Curly Braces for Array Literals
description.body:
Enable this to use curly braces `{}` instead of square brackets `[]` for defining array literals.

Defaults to: **`off`**.

When enabled, all variable declarations in HTVM will be transpiled to `var` in JavaScript output.

Defaults to: **`on`**.

description.header: JS Target: Output Full HTML File
description.body:
When enabled, the JavaScript output will be wrapped in a basic HTML structure (`<html>`, `<head>`, `<body>`, `<script>`). Useful for direct browser execution or GUI apps. If disabled, outputs only the JS code.

Defaults to: **`off`**.

description.header: JS Target: Wrap Code in Main Function
description.body:
When enabled, the main body of the transpiled JavaScript code will be wrapped inside a function (often `async function main() { ... } main();`), otherwise it runs in the global scope.

Defaults to: **`off`**.

description.header: JS Target: Make All Functions Async
description.body:
When enabled, all functions defined in HTVM will be transpiled with the `async` keyword in JavaScript output, unless explicitly overridden.

Defaults to: **`off`**.

When enabled, forces the use of `===` in JavaScript output even if the HTVM code used `==`. If disabled, `==` in HTVM map to `==` in JS.

Defaults to: **`off`**.
